title-group.article-title: Diterpenoids from the genus Euphorbia: Structure and biological activity (2013-2019)

kwd.tp:taxon-name: E. nema tocypha ( Chen et al., 2014b )

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Review

Diterpenoids from the genus
Euphorbia
: Structure and biological activity (2013–2019)

Yang Xu a , Peiyu Tang a , Man Zhu a , Yali Wang a , Dejuan Sun
a, *** , Hua Li
a, b, ** , Lixia Chen
a, *

a Wuya College of Innovation, Key Laboratory of Structure-Based Drug Design
&
Discovery, Ministry of Education, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Shenyang, 110016, People’ s Republic of China

b
School of Pharmacy, Tongji Medical College, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430030, People’ s Republic of China
ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Diterpenoid
Skeleton
Biological activity
ABSTRACT

Euphorbiaceae is one of the largest families of higher plants, including 7500 species, and many of them are used as medicines in China . From 2013 to 2019, a total of 455 previously undescribed diterpenoids were isolated from 53 species of
Euphorbia ,
and some skeleton types were first discovered from the genus
Euphorbia .
Most of the diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia spp
. have been tested for their biological activity, and some of them were first reported for
Euphorbia
diterpenoids in recent years, such as neuroprotection, antimalarial activity and inhibition of osteoclast formation. In this review, we summarize all the isolated diterpenoids from the genus
Euphorbia
according to their skeleton types , classify all these diterpenoids into 26 normal classes and 37 novel skeleton types , and summarize their biological activity.

sec.title: 1. Methodology
sec.p:
The references of this paper were obtained from SciFinder. After entering SciFinder, we enter research topic as “
Euphorbia
”, then refine research topic as “compound”, language as “English”, publication year as “2013–2019”, document type without “patent”, and finally got 1470 results. From 1470 results, the research literatures on the separation of new compounds were selected. In order to avoid misunderstanding of diterpenoid skeleton, some articles about norditerpenes and diterpenoid dimers were deleted, and a total of 113 related literatures were obtained.

sec.title: 2. Introduction
sec.p:
Euphorbiaceae , one of the largest families of higher plants, comprises approximately 50 tribes, 300 genera, and 7500 species, with the highest species richness in many habitats (
). In China , some plants from the genus
Euphorbia
are used as medicines with the functions of itching relief, detoxification, expectoration, abdominal pain, abdominal distention, skin disease, and paralysis (
). In recent years, many scientists have investigated the active ingredients of
Euphorbia
plants.

Diterpenoids possess various skeleton types , such as cembrane, ent - abietane, ent -rosane and jatrophane. The genus
Euphorbia
is an important resource for natural diterpenoids. An increasing number of diterpenoids have been obtained from
Euphorbia
in recent years. Some skeletons have never been isolated from the genus
Euphorbia
before, including dolabrane, ent -isopimarane, ent -labdane, cembrane, gaditanone, ingol, jatropholane, presegetane, segetane, expoxyjatropholane, and cyclojatrophane diterpenoids.

sec.title: 3. The isolated diterpenoids
sec.p: Diterpenoids are composed of 4 isoprene units and 20 carbon atoms in their skeletons, which are derived from the precursor geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate (GGPP) and show diverse structures. Generally, there are two different methods for diterpenoid cyclization as shown in Fig. 1 , which determine the classification of high-grade or low-grade diterpenoids. Diterpenoids with various skeletons are all derived from the first two cyclization products.

More than 400 diterpenoids have been isolated and structurally elucidated from the genus
Euphorbia
since 2013. All the diteropenoids are classified as higher diterpenoids and lower diterpenoids. The detailed skeleton types are shown in Fig. 2.

sec.title: 3.1. Higher diterpenoids
sec.p:
Among all the diterpenoids of the Euphorbiaceae family, the skeletons of “higher diterpenoids” involve the classical “concertina-like” cyclization of the precursor, which finally forms various cyclized hydrocarbon structures (
). The higher diterpenoids usually possess 6/6/6 three-membered rings in their scaffolds. Among all of the diterpenoids found from the genus
Euphorbia
in 2013–2019, the higher diterpenoids contain labdane, abietane, atisane, kaurane, isopimarane, rosane and dolabrane types . All these higher diterpenoids from the genus
Euphorbia
are listed in Table 1. The transformation relationship between these higher diterpenoids is shown in Fig. 3.

sec.title: 3.1.1. Dolabrane
sec.p:
The dolabrane diterpenoids derived from rosane diterpenoids through C-19 methyls are transferred from C-4 to C-5. There are very few dolabrane diterpenoids from the
Euphorbia
genus.

obtained a dolabrane diterpenoid ( 1 ) from
E. rapulum ,
and its structure was elucidated by means of various spectroscopic methods (
).

It may be that the transformation of GGPP into dolabrane diterpenoids requires many transformation processes, which leads to rare amounts of dolabrane diterpenoids in nature. In recent years, only one dolabrane diterpenoid has been isolated from
Euphorbia
, and dolabrane diterpenoid is the only diterpenoid skeleton with only one methyl group at C-4.
3.1.2. Abietane

Abietane-type diterpenoids feature a tricyclic skeleton based on a phenanthrene hydride. Some characteristic groups are present in the skeleton, including a gem-dimethyl group at C-4, a methyl group at C-10, and an isopropyl group at C-13.

Six abietane-type diterpenoids, euphoroids A-C (
20 – 22
) (
), ebracteolata D ( 23 ) (
), ebractenoid Q ( 24 ) (
), and ebractenoid N ( 25 ) (
) were obtained from the roots of
E. ebracteolata
, and their structures were elucidated on the basis of spectroscopic data. Phytochemical investigation of whole plants of
E. pilosa
led to the isolation and identification of an abietane diterpenoid, euphopilolide ( 26 ) (
).
got two abietane diterpenoids (
27 – 28
) from the methanolic extract of
E. piscatoria .
Compound 28 , an unusual structure, was considered as an intermediate in the biosynthesis of abietane α , β -unsaturated lactones, which commonly exist in
Euphorbia species
(
). Two ent -abietane diterpenoids (
29 – 30
) were isolated from the methanolic extract of the stems of
E. royleana ( Wang et al., 2019a )
. Zhao et al., (2014) found five abietane-type diterpenoids, eurifoloids C-G (
31 – 35
) from
E. neriifolia ( Zhao et al., 2014 )
. An abietane diterpenoid stracheyioid C ( 36 ) was obtained from the whole plants of
E. stracheyi ( Yang et al., 2014 )
.
got an abietane diterpenoid lactone ( 37 ) from the ethanol extract of the whole plants of
E. lunulata ( Liu et al., 2014a )
. A phytochemical investigation on the aerial parts of
E. helioscopia
led to the isolation of 14 highly oxygenated abietane-type diterpenoids, euphelionolides A-N (
38 – 51
) which were previously undescribed (
). Three abietane-type diterpenoids, 2α- hydroxy- ent -abieta-8,13-dien-12,16-olide ( 52 ) (
), 17-nor-7 α -hydroxy- 15-oxoabieta-8,11,13-triene ( 53 ) (
), and jolkinolide F ( 54 ) (
) were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. laurifolia
, roots of
E. pekinensis
, and roots of
E. jolkinii
, respectively. Three abietane-type diterpenoids, 3-hydoxy-19--cyclopropenoyloxy-abietane ( 55 ), ent -abieta-9,12,14-triene-12,16-olide ( 56 ) and 12,19-dihydroxy-abieta-5-ene ( 57 ) were isolated from
E. pseudocactus ( Abdel-Monem and Abdelrahman, 2016 )
. Two abietane diterpenoids, named euphcopenoids A ( 58 ) and B ( 59 ), were isolated from the whole plant of
E. helioscopia ( Yin et al., 2020 )
.

Interestingly, most of the abietane diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
have an additional five-membered lactone ring. Many hydroxyl groups in abietane diterpenoids also make them easy to form lactone rings, such as compounds 2 , 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 . Similarly, they also easily form double bonds by elimination reaction, such as compounds 3 , 4 , 5 , 7 . Among them, compound 58 possesses a special skeleton with its C ring becoming a benzene ring. Moreover, in compound 22 , the substituent of long-chain fatty acids is very rare.
3.1.3. Atisane

C-16 and C-8 of isopimarane-type diterpenoids are connected together, and then C-15 migrates and links with C-12 to form atisane-type diterpenoids. The two types of atisane skeletons ( A and B ) can transform into each other as shown in Fig. 4 .

got 9 atisane-type diterpenoids, antiquorpenes A I (
60 – 68
) from
E. antiquorum ( Liang et al., 2019 )
. In the same plant,
obtained an ent -atisane type diterpenoid atisane-3α, 16α, 17-triol ( 69 ) (
).

isolated two atisane-type diterpenoids ( 82–83 ) from the methanol extract of the stems of
E. royleana ( Wang et al., 2019a )
. Through the phytochemical investigation on the fresh roots of
E. jolkinii, Huang et al. (2014)
got an atisane-type diterpenoid ( 84 ) (
). Two atisane type diterpenoids possessing an extra unusual 2-oxopropyl moiety ( 85–86 ) (
), and two atisane diterpenoids, ent -atisane-16 β , 17-isopropylidenedioxy-19-ol-3-one ( 87 ) and ent -atisane-16 β , 17-isopropylidenedioxy-11 β , 18-dihydroxyl-3-one ( 88 ) (
) were isolated from the roots of
E. ebracteolata
and the whole plants of
E. wallichii ,
respectively. Their structures were elucidated on the basis of extensive spectroscopic analyses. An ent -atisane diterpenoid, ent -3 α -acetoxy-1 β ,16 β ,17-trihydroxyatisane ( 89 ), was isolated from the aerial parts of
E. antiquorum ( Tran et al., 2021 )
.

C-3 of all atisane-type diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
is always oxidized, such as compounds 55 , 56 , 62 . Moreover, among all the atisane diterpenoids, the number of type B diterpenoids is much greater than that of type A diterpenoids. Only compounds 69 , 80 , 81 , 87 , 88 and 89 belong to type A, and the rest belong to type B.

sec.title: 3.1.4. Pimarane
sec.p: Pimarane diterpenoids may be formed by the connection of C-17 and C-13 of labdane diterpenoids.

Five isopimarane-type diterpenoids, eurifoloids I-M (
90 – 94
), were isolated from
E. neriifolia ( Zhao et al., 2014 )
.
isolated thirteen isopimarane diterpenoids (
95 – 107
) from the roots of
E. hylonoma ( Wei et al., 2018a )
. Phytochemical investigation on the fresh roots of
E. jolkinii
afforded 21 diterpenoids, including three isopimarane type diterpenoids, (3 β ,12 β )-3,12-dihydroxyisopimara-7, 15-dien-2-one ( 108 ), (3β,12 β )-3,12-dihydroxyisopimara-7,15-diene ( 109 ) and (12 β )-2,12-dihydroxy isopimara- 1,7,15-trien-3-one ( 110 ) (
). Eight isopimarane diterpenoids, (5 β , 9 β ,10 α , 12 α )-2,12-dihydroxypimara-1,7,15-trien-3-one ( 111 ), (5 β ,9 β , 10 α )-2-hydroxypimara-1,7,15-trien-3-one ( 112 ), (3 β ,11 α ,13 α )-3, 11-dihydroxypimara-7,15-diene-2,12-dione ( 113 ) (
),

euphorbesulin P ( 114 ) (
), altavnols A-C (
115 – 117
) (
) and ent -8(14)-pimarene-12 β ,15 S ,16-triol ( 118 ) (
) were isolated from the roots of
E. pekinensis ,
the twigs of
E. esula ,
the whole areal parts of
E. alatavica
and the roots of
E. fischeriana ,
respectively.
Most of the pimarane diterpenoids have double bonds between C-15 and C-16, except for compound 118 . It should be noted that all the pimarana diterpenoids possess oxygen-substituted groups at C-12.

sec.title: 3.1.5. Kaurane
sec.p: For the source of kaurane diterpenoids, C-16 and C-8 of isopimarane diterpenoids are connected together, and then the C-17 methyl group migrates from C-13 to C-15.

In recent years, only five kaurane diterpenoids have been isolated from the
Euphorbia
genus. ( 4R, 5 S, 8 S,9R, 10 S, 13 R, 16 S )- ent -16 α ,17-dihydroxy-19-butyryloxykauran-3-one ( 119 ) (
), (4 R, 5 S, 8 S, 9 R, 10 S, 13 R, 16 S )- ent -16 α ,17-dihydroxy-19-(2 ξ -methylbutanoyloxy) kauran-3- one ( 120 ), ( 4R, 5 S, 8 S, 9 R, 10 S, 13 R, 16 S )- ent -16 α ,17-dihydroxy-19-tigloyloxykauran-3-one ( 121 ) (
), 16-epi-18-hydroxy-abbeokutone ( 122 ) (
) and ent -kaurane-16 β , 17,19-triol-3-one ( 123 ) (
) were isolated from
E. antiquorum ,
the stems of
E. royleana ,
the aerial parts of
E. helioscopia
and the whole plants
E. stracheyi
, respectively.
According to the structures of the isolated kaurane diterpenoids, the configuration of C-8 is a fixed α configuration, and C-3 is oxidized to ketone carbonyl.

sec.title: 3.1.6. Labdane
sec.p: Labdane diterpenoids are bicyclic structures, with decalin as the parent nucleus, including its demethylation, cleavage and rearrangement derivatives, which could be considered the precursor of higher
diterpenoids.

Two labdane diterpenoids, ent -3 α ,16-dihydroxylabda-8(17), 12 ( E ),14-triene ( 124 ) and ent -14( S ), 15-dihydroxylabda-8(17)-12( E )-dien- 18-oic acid ( 125 ), were isolated from the roots of
E. yinshanica ( Zhang et al., 2017a )
. An labdane type diterpenoid, 2,13,9-trihydroxy-labda-8 (17),12( E ),14-triene ( 126 ), was isolated from
E. rapulum ( Liu et al., 2016b )
.

Labdane diterpenoids are rarely found in the
Euphorbia
genus. In recent years, only these three labdane diterpenoids have been isolated from
Euphorbia
.

sec.title: 3.1.7. Rosane
sec.p: The C-20 methyl of isopimarane diterpenoids is transferred from C-10 to C-9 to form rosane diterpenoids.

Euphorpekones A ( 127 ) and B ( 128 ), two rosane type diterpenoids, were isolated from
E. pekinensis ( Fang et al., 2015 )
.
got two rosane-type diterpenoid, 3,20-dihydroxy- ent -1(10),

15-rosadiene ( 129 ) and dihydroxy- ent -1(10), 15-rosadiene ( 130 ) from the roots of
E. fischeriana ( Wang et al., 2013 )
. In the phytochemical investigation on the acetone extract of
E. milii, Liu et al. (2017a)
got thirteen rosane diterpenoids, euphominoids A-M (
131 – 143
) (
).
There are always hydroxyl groups on C-3 and C- 18 in rosane diterpenoids, making them easy to form a new ring, such as compounds 134 , 149 and 151 .

sec.title: 3.2. Lower diterpenoids
sec.p:
Macrocyclic diterpenoids and their cyclization products can be classified as “lower terpenoids” (“ Euphorbiaceae diterpenoids”) derived from a geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate precursor through a “head-to-tail” cyclization. Lower diterpenoids are characteristic compounds of both Euphorbiaceae and Thymelaeaceae , showing their chemotaxonomic relevance (
). Among all of the diterpenoids found in 2013–2019, the lower diterpenoids include casbane, cembrane, rharnnofolane, gaditanone, ingenane, ingol, jatrophane, jatropholane, lathyrane, cyclomyrsinol, myrsinol, premyrsinol, paraliane, pepluane, presegetane, segetane, tigliane, cyclojatrophane and expoxyjatropholane. All of the lower diterpenoids are listed in Table 2, and the transformation relationship between lower diterpenoids is shown in Fig. 5.

sec.title: 3.2.1. Casbane and cembrane
sec.p: Cembrane diterpenoids are large ring diterpenoids formed by four isoprene units end-to-end. They are natural products with fourteenmembered rings and three symmetrical methyls and one isopropyl group. Casbane diterpenoids are formed by the connection of C-15 and C- 2 in cembrane diterpenoids. They are considered the precursors of most macrocyclic diterpenoids.

Only one cembrane diterpenoid was isolated from the
Euphorbia
genus, named ()-(1 S )-15-hydroxy-18-carboxycembrene ( 156 ), a poorpolarity diterpenoid isolated from the petroleum ether extract of the roots of
E. pekinensis ( Hou et al., 2013 )
.

Cembrane-type and caspane-type diterpenes usually have double bonds between C-7 and C-8 and between C-11 and C-12. Their biosynthesis pathway is that the 15-hydroxyl group of cembrane-type diterpenes dehydrates to form double bonds, and then the Δ 4,5 double bond and Δ 2,3 double bond have 1-4 addition reaction to form a ternary ring and Δ 3,4 double bond.

sec.title: 3.2.2. Rhamnofolane
sec.p: Rhamnofolane diterpenoid is formed by the cyclization of C-6/C-10 and C-5/C-14 from cembrane diterpenoid. At present, rhamnofolane diterpenoids are mainly isolated from Euphorbiaceae . Because the only difference between rhamnofolane and daphnane diterpenoids is the different substituting position of isopropyl on ring C, they are often easily confused ( Fig. 6 ).

In the phytochemical investigation of whole plants of
E. pilosa, Zhang et al. (2014)
isolated two rhamnofolane-diterpenoid glucosides, euphopilosides A and B (
164 – 165)
(
). Chemical investigation on the roots of
E. fischeriana
led to the isolation of a rhamnofolane-type diterpenoid, langduin A ( 166 ) (
).

sec.title: 3.2.3. Gaditanone
sec.p: C-12/C-15/C-11/C-6 of jatrophane-type diterpenoids were linked to form a four membered ring and then became gaditanone-type
diterpenoids.

A diterpenoid, gaditanone ( 167 ), with an unprecedented 5/6/4/6- fused gaditanane tetracyclic skeleton, was isolated from the aerial part of
E. gaditana ( Flores-Giubi et al., 2017 )
. This is the first example of gaditanone diterpenoid isolated from
Euphorbia
genus.

Although gaditanone-type diterpenes have multiple oxygen-containing substituents, double bonds may form when the oxygen-containing substituents at C-3 are removed. So Δ 2,3 double bond may appear in this skeleton.
3.2.4. Ingenane
The ingenane-type diterpenoids are produced through the rearrangement of tigliane-type diterpenoids as shown in Fig. 7 .

Two ingenane diterpenoids, ingenol-3-palmitate ( 168 ) and 3-O-(9
′ E - hexadecenoyl)ingenol ( 169 ) were isolated from the roots of
E. ebracteolata
by bioassay-guided fractionation together with UPLC- MSn analysis (
).
got two ingenane-type diterpenoids, (3 S, 4 S, 5 R, 8 S, 10 S, 11 R, 13 R, 14 R, 15 R )-3 β -O -angeloyl-17-tigloyloxy-20-deoxyingenol ( 170 ) and (3 S, 4 S, 5 R, 8 S, 10 S, 11 R, 13 R, 14 R, 15 R )-3 β -O -angeloyl-17-benzoyloxy-20-deoxyingenol ( 171 ) from the methanolic extract of the stems of
E. royleana ( Wang et al., 2019a )
. Eurifoloid A-B (
172 – 173)
(
), 20- O -[(20 E , 40 E )-6-oxo-20,40-hexadienoyl] ingenol ( 174 ), 20- O -[(20 E ,40 E , 60 E )-8-oxo-20,40,60-octatrienoyl] ingenol ( 175 ) (
), euphorkans A-B (
176 – 177
) (
), ingenol 6,7-epoxy-3-tetradecanoate ( 178 ) (
), 20-deoxy-16-hydroxyingenol-3- β -D-glucopyranoside ( 179 ) (
), 7, 13-diacetyl-5-angeloyl-20-nicotinyl-3-propionyl-1,2,6,7-tetrahydroingenol ( 180 ) (
) and stracheyioids B ( 181 ) (
), were isolated from
E. neriifolia
, the roots of
E. jolkinii
, the roots of
E. kansui
, the roots of
E. fischeriana
, the aerial parts of
E. laurifolia
,
E. erythradenia
and the whole plant of
E. stracheyi
, respectively.

Among the ingenane diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
, C-9 is oxidized to ketone carbonyl. Moreover, the multiple hydroxyl groups in the structure also make the structure of ingenane diterpenoids more variable.
3.2.5. Ingol
C-4 and C-15 of lathyrane diterpenes are linked by ether bonds to form a ternary ring, which is called ingol diterpenoid.

Two ingol-type diterpenoids, euphoresins A-B (
182 – 183
), have been isolated from the methanol extract of the latex of
E. resinifera ( Wang et al., 2019b )
. Eighteen ingol-type diterpenoids, euphorantins A R (
184 – 201
), along with four known analogues, were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. antiquorum .
Among them, compounds
184 – 186
are the first examples of C-17-oxygenated ingol-type diterpenoids, while compounds
199 – 201
are 2,3-di-epimers of ingol analogues, which are very rare and have only been found in
E. bungei
and
E. canariensis ( Qi et al., 2014 )
. Two ingol-type diterpenoids, euphorantins S-T (
202 – 203
), were isolated from
E. neriifolia ( Yan et al., 2018 )
.
At present, isolated ingol diterpenoids have an epoxy ring at C-4 and C-6, and C-14 is also oxidized to ketone carbonyl. Surprisingly, free
hydroxyl groups are rarely found in ingol-type diterpenoids, and most of them are esterified.

sec.title: 3.2.6. Jatrophane
sec.p:
Jatrophane diterpenoids are formed by the cyclization of C-6 and C-10 and the opening of a single bond between C-1 and C-2 of casbane diterpenoids. Jatrophane diterpenoids have been the most common type isolated from
Euphorbia
in recent years. From 2013 to 2019, a total of 104 jatrophane diterpenoids were obtained from
Euphorbia
.

A series of structurally related jatrophane analogues, including the euphosquamosins A-C (
228 – 230
), were purified from the Iranian spurge
E. squamosa ( Rawal et al., 2014 )
. The phytochemical investigation of the whole plant of
E. glomerulans
resulted in the isolation of 17 jatrophane diterpenoids (
231 – 247
) from the whole plants of
E. glomerulans ( Hasan et al., 2019 )
.
got nine jatrophane diterpenoids (
248 – 256
) from the methanol extract of
E. dulcis ( Kusz et al., 2018 )
. A jatrophane-type diterpenoid, 14 α ,15 β -diacetoxy-3 α ,7 β -dibenzoyloxy -9-oxo-2 β H,13 α Hjatropha-5 E ,11 E -diene ( 257 ), was isolated from the ethanol extract of the whole plant of
E. lunulata ( Liu et al., 2014a )
. Six jatrophane diterpenoid esters (
258 – 263
) were obtained from the acetone extract of fructus of
E. sororia ( Lu et al., 2014 )
. A jatrophane diterpenoid ( 258 ) with an endo-type conformation was isolated from the methanol extract of the whole plant of
E. taurinensis ( Redei et al., 2018 )
. Seven jatrophane diterpenoids, nicaeenin A-G (
265 – 271
), were isolated from the latex of
E. nicaeensis
collected in Serbia (
).
got a jatrophane ( 272 ) from the aerial parts of
E. gaditana ( Flores-Giubi et al., 2017 )
. 19 jatrophane-type diterpenoids, including 5 ones, euphodendroidins P-T (
273 – 277
), were isolated from
E. dendroides ( Esposito et al., 2017 )
. Two jatrophane diterpenoids, guyonianin G ( 278 ) and H ( 279 ), were separated from the methanol extract of
E. guyoniana ( Kusz et al., 2016 )
.
obtained 11 jatrophane diterpenoids, named euphorbesulins D N (
280 – 290
) from the aqueous ethanol extracts of powdered twigs of
E. esula ( Zhou et al., 2016 )
. Bioactivity-guided fractionation of the MeOH extract from the roots of
E. kansui
resulted in the isolation of two jatrophane-type diterpenoids, kanesulones A ( 291 ) and B ( 292 ) (
).
gained two jatrophane-type diterpenoids, named welwitschene ( 293 ) and epoxywelwitschene ( 294 ) from the methanolic extract of
E. welwitschii ,
and C-15 and C-12 of compound 293 form a special five-membered ring through ether bond (
). Phytochemical investigation of the MeOH extract obtained from the aerial parts of
E. exigua
resulted in the isolation of two jatrophane type diterpenoids ( 295–296 ) (
). From the whole plant of
E. cyparissias
, two diterpenoids based on jatrophane skeleton, named cyparissins A and B (
297 – 298
) were obtained (
). A dichloromethane–acetone extract of
E. osyridea
, afforded three jatrophane diterpenoids (
299 – 301
) belonging to the 2,3,5,7,8,9,14, 15-octahydroxy-jatropha-6(17),11 E -diene class, along with three known triterpenes (
). Acetone-chloroform (1:2) extract of the aerial parts of
E. connata
was investigated for its diterpenoids, leading to the isolation of a jatrophane type diterpenoid, named 5, 6-epoxy-8,9,15-triacetyl-3-benzoyl-14-oxo-jatropha-11( E )-ene ( 302 ) (
). Five jatrophane diterpenoids, named euphosorophanes A-E (
303 – 307
), were isolated from the fructus of
E. sororia ( Hu et al., 2018 )
.

Jatrophane diterpenoids are the most widely isolated diterpenoids from
Euphorbia
. Its C-3, C-5, C-7, C-9, C-11, C-14, and C-15 are often replaced by oxygen-containing groups. The changes of groups and a series of reactions at these positions also make their structures diversify. Among these isolated compounds, 207 is very special because of the
connection between C-5 and C-12.

sec.title: 3.2.7. Jatropholane
sec.p: Jatropholane diterpenoids are formed by the cyclization of C-12 and C- 5 in lathyrane diterpenoids.

Gao and Asia (2017) got a jatropholane type diterpenoid ( 309 ), named soongajatrophol, from an acetone extract of
E. soongarica ( Gao and Aisa, 2017 )
. Four jatropholane-type diterpenoids (
310 – 313
), named sikkimenoids A D, were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. sikkimensis ( Yang et al., 2013 )
. It should be noted that all these five jatrophorane diterpenoids possess carbonyl groups at C-3 position.

To date, few jatrophorane diterpenoids have been found in species other than plants of the
Euphorbia
genus. Moreover, the number of jatropholane diterpenoids is also very small, probably due to the difficulty of synthesizing pathways of other biogenic compounds. It should be noted that all jatropholane diterpenoids have ketone carbonyl groups at C-3 and Δ 4,15 and Δ 6,17 double bonds.

sec.title: 3.2.8. Lathyrane
sec.p: Lathyrane diterpenoids are derived from the cyclization of C-6 and C-10 in casbane diterpenoids. Because of its unique 5/11/3 ring system, lathyrane-type diterpenoids have become the precursors of many macrocyclic diterpenoids.

obtained two lathyrane-type macrocyclic diterpenoids, piscatoriols A and B (
331 – 332)
from the methanol extract of
E. piscatoria ,
and the presence of hydroxyls at C-3 and C- 5 in 331 and 332 are uncommon in lathyrane diterpenoids, different from most compounds with the formation of esters (
). Two lathyrane-type diterpenoids, kansuingols A ( 333 ) and B ( 334 ), were isolated from the roots of
E. kansui ( Kim et al., 2018 )
.
got a lathyrane type diterpenoid ( 335 ) from
E. aellenii
, which is a rare 6(17)-epoxylathyrane diterpenoid (
). Two lathyrane-type diterpenoids, soongalathyrones A and B (
336 – 337
), were isolated from an acetone extract of
E. soongarica ( Gao and Aisa, 2017 )
. Five lathyrane diterpenoids, euphordracunculin C ( 338 ) (
), ebracteolatas C ( 339 ) (
), laurifolioside ( 340 ), 2- epi -laurifolioside ( 341 ) and 7 β ,8 α ,15 β -triacetoxy-3 β- (2-methylpropan oyloxy)-4 α ,9 αH ,11 αH -lathyra-5 E ,12 E -dien- 14-one ( 342 ) (
), were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. dracunculoides
, the roots of
E. ebracteolata
, the aerial parts of
E. laurifolia
and
E. aellenii
, respectively. Phytochemical analysis of
E. sogdiana
afforded three diterpenoids with the rare 6(17)-epoxylathyrane skeleton (
343 – 345
) from
E. aellenii ( Yazdiniapour et al., 2016 )
. Two macrocyclic diterpenoids, 2- epi -latazienone ( 346 ) and 15 β -acetoxy-7 β -nicotinoyloxy-3 β , 8 α -di-(2-methylpropanoyloxy)-4 α H,9 α H,11 α H- lathyra-5 E ,12 E -dien-14 -one ( 347 ) were obtained from
E. laurifolia ( Duran-Pena et al., 2017 )
.

All the isolated lathyrane diterpenoids contain a C-14 ketone carbonyl group, except for compounds 333 and 334 . Most lathyrane diterpenoids have Δ 12,13 double bonds, in addition to compounds 327 , 340 and 341 .

sec.title: 3.2.9. Cyclomyrsinol
sec.p: Cyclomyrsinol diterpenoids are formed by the connection of C-9 and C-18 through a single bond of myrsinol diterpenoids. They belong to myrsinane diterpenoids containing spiral structures.

Two cyclomyrsinol esters, 3- O -propionyl-5,10,14- O -triacetyl-8- O - (20 -methylbutanoyl)-cyclomyrsinol ( 348 ) and 3,5,10,14,15- O -pentaacetyl-8- O -isobutanoyl- cyclomyrsinol ( 349 ) were isolated from the methanol extract of the aerial parts of
E. microsciadia ( Ghanadian et al.,

2013a). Acetone-chloroform (1:2) extracts of the aerial parts of
E. kopetdaghi
were investigated to afford three pentacyclic myrisinanes (
350 – 352
) (
).
got three cyclomyrsinol diterpenoids (
353 – 355
) from the aerial parts of
E. sogdiana ( Zolfaghari et al., 2016 )
. Phytochemical investigation of the aerial parts of
E. dracunculoides
led to the isolation of three cyclomyrsinol-type diterpenoids (
356 – 358
) (
). A cyclomyrsinol-type diterpenoid ( 359 ), 3,5,10,14,15- O -pentaacetyl-8- O -benzoylcyclomyrsinol was isolated from the roots of
E. nema tocypha ( Chen et al., 2014b )
. Phytochemical investigation of the plant
E. prolifera
led to the isolation of a cyclomyrsinol type diterpenoid ( 360 ), which named prolifepene A (
).
Surprisingly, C-17 and C-13 of all cyclomyrsinol diterpenes are linked by an ether bond to form a five-membered ring.

sec.title: 3.2.10. Myrsinol
sec.p: Myrsinol diterpenoids are formed by C-9 and C-10 bond breaking of premyrinol diterpenoids. They belong to myrsinane-type diterpenoids.

Similar to cyclomyrsinol diterpenoids, C-13 and C-17 of myrsinol diterpenoids are linked by ether bonds to form a five-membered ring. The main difference between myrsinol-type diterpenoids and cyclomyrinol-type diterpenoids is that C-18 and C-9 do not connect together to form a four-membered ring in myrsinol-type diterpenoids, but they generally have Δ 8,9 double bond.

sec.title: 3.2.11. Premyrsinol
sec.p: Premyrsinol diterpenoids are formed by the cyclization at C-12 and C-6 of lathyrane diterpenoids. It belongs to myrsinane-type diterpenoid.

Phytochemical investigation of
E. prolifera
afforded four premyrsinol type diterpenoids, named euphorbialoid K-M (
373 – 375
) (
), and prolifepene B ( 376 ) (
).
isolated three premyrsinane diterpenoids (
377 – 379)
from the aerial parts of
E. sogdiana ( Zolfaghari et al., 2016 )
. Four premyrsinol type diterpenoids, euphordraculoins J L (
380 – 382
)(
) and premylanin ( 383 ) (
) were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. dracunculoides
and the seeds of
E. lathyris
, respectively.
got a premyrsinane-type diterpenoid polyester, 3 β -O -isobutyryl-5α- O -benzoyl-7 β ,13 β -di- O -acetyl-17- O -nicotinoylpre myrsinol ( 384 ) from
E. dracunculoides ( Wang et al., 2015e )
. Elshamy et al. (2019) got three premyrsinol-type diterpenoids, euphosantiananes E-G (
385 – 387
) from
E. sanctae-catharinae (Elshamy et al., 2019)
.

The main difference between premyrsinol and cycolmyrsinol diterpenoids is the formation of a ring by the connection of C-9 and C- 10 in premyrsinol diterpenoids, rather than a linkage of C-9 with C-18 to form a four-membered ring. All of the premyrsinol diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
possess ester bonds at C-3, which make their structures diverse.

sec.title: 3.2.12. Paraliane
sec.p: Paraliane diterpenoids are formed by C-6/C-13 cyclization of the presegetane diterpenoids. Aqueous ethanol extract of powdered twigs of

E. esula
afforded a paraliane-type diterpenoid, named euphorbesulin O ( 388 ) (
). Four paraliane-type diterpenoids, paralianones A D (
389 – 392
), were isolated from an acetone extract of
E. peplus ( Wan et al., 2016a )
.

Very few diterpenoids of the paraliane type have been found in nature, and only five analogues have been obtained from
Euphorbia
in recent years.

sec.title: 3.2.13. Pepluane
sec.p: The breaking of the chemical bond between C-9/C-10 and then cyclization of C-18/C-10 of paraliane diterpenoids produced pepluane diterpenoids.

Eight pepluane diterpenoids with rare skeleton named pepluanols A H (
393 – 400)
, were isolated from an acetone extract of
E. peplus ( Wan et al., 2016a )
.
Pepluane diterpenoids have fixed oxygen substitutions at C-3, C-5, C- 8, C-9, C-11, C-15 and C-16. If these oxygen substitutions disappear, some double bonds may be formed at these positions.

sec.title: 3.2.14. Presegetane
sec.p:
Presegetane diterpenoids are derived from the C-12/C-8 cyclization of jatrophane diterpenoids. In recent years, presegetane diterpenoids have only been isolated from
E. esula
.

Three presegetane type diterpenoids (
401 – 403
), named euphorbesulins A P were isolated from the ethanol extract of powdered twigs of
E. esula ( Zhou et al., 2016 )
.

sec.title: 3.2.15. Segetane
sec.p: Segetane diterpenoids are formed by C-17/C-13 cyclization of the presegetane diterpenoids.

A segetane ( 404 ) was isolated from the methanol extract of the whole plant of
E. taurinensis
, which was the only segetane-type diterpenoid from
Euphorbia ( Redei et al., 2018 )
.

sec.title: 3.2.16. Tigliane
sec.p: Tigliane diterpenoids are formed by the cyclization at C-8/C-14 of lathyrane diterpenoids.

4,20-Dideoxy-4 α -phorbol-12 β -acetate-13 α -isobutyrate ( 405 ) (
), 12-deoxyphorbol-13-dimethylpentadecanoate ( 406) (
), stracheyioids A ( 407 ) (
), 9-deoxy-11 β -hydroxyprostratin ( 408 ), 20-oxo-prostratin ( 409 ), 20-O-(4
′
-galloyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( 410 ), 20- O -(3
′
-galloyl)- β -D-glu copyranoside ( 411 ) (
), 12-deoxyphorbol-13-(7 Z ) -hexadecenoate ( 412 ), 12-deoxyphorbol-13-(9 Z ,12 Z )-octadecadienoate ( 413 ) and 12-deoxyphorbol-13-(6 Z )-octadecenoate ( 414 ) (
), a total of ten tigliane type diterpenoids were obtained from the latex and roots of
E. clementei
, the roots of
E. fischeriana
, the whole plant of
E. stracheyi ,
the roots of
E. fischeriana
and the latex of
E. fischeriana
, respectively.
All of the tigliane diterpenoids possess Δ 1,2 and Δ 6,7 double bonds and keto groups at C-3.

sec.title: 3.2.17. Cyclojatrophane and expoxyjatropholane
sec.p: Cyclojatrophane diterpenoids are produced by the C-17/C-12 cyclization of jatrophane diterpenoids. The expoxyjatropholane diterpenoid is formed by breaking the chemical bond of C-7/C-8 of jatrophane diterpenoids. These two types of diterpenoids are rare compared with other diterpenoids.

Two cyclojatrophane-type diterpenoids, euphowelwitschines A-B (
415 – 416
) were isolated from the methanol extract of
E. welwitschii ( Reis et al., 2015 )
. Two previously undescribed expoxyjatrophola ne-type diterpenoids, secoheliosphanes A-B (
417 – 418
) were isolated from the whole plant of
E. helioscopia ( Mai et al., 2018b )
.

sec.title: 3.3. Diterpenoids with novel skeletons
sec.p:
With the increase in research on the genus
Euphorbia
, many diterpenoids with novel skeletons have been found. They were speculated to be derivatives of known diterpenoids. Thirty-seven diterpenoids with novel skeletons were isolated from the genus
Euphorbia
as listed in Table 3.

Two
Euphorbia
diterpenoids with a novel 4-(5,5-dimethylheptan-2- yl)-2,7-dimethylbicyclo[4.3.0]nonane skeleton, Euphorhelipanes A ( 433 ) and B ( 434 ) were isolated from the whole plants of
E. helioscopia ( Li et al., 2019 )
, and two jatrophane-derived diterpenoids heliojatrones A and B (
435 – 436
) with an unprecedented trans-bicyclo[8.3.0] tridecane core were also isolated from the same plant (
).

Two diterpenoids, possessing 5/6/7/3 fused-ring skeletons (
442 – 443
), were isolated from an acetone extract of
E. soongarica ( Gao and Aisa, 2017 )
.\ Three highly modified ent -rosane diterpenoids, euphomilones A ( 444 ) and B ( 445 ), and euphomianol A ( 446 ), were isolated from the aerial parts of
E. milii ( Liu et al., 2016a )
. Euphorikanin A ( 447 ), an unprecedented diterpenoid lactone which possesses a 5/6/7/3-fused tetracyclic ring skeleton, was isolated from the roots of
E. kansui ( Fei et al., 2016 )
. Three highly modified cembranoids, quorumolides A C (
448 – 450
), were isolated from
E. antiquorum
. Compound 448 is the first example of a cembranoid embedding an α,β -unsaturated- γ -lactone and a tetrahydro-2H-pyran motif within the 14-membered ring (
). Euphorkanlide A ( 451 ) is a highly modified ingenane diterpenoid with a C 24 appendage that forms an additional hexahydroisobenzofuran-fused 19-membered macrocyclic bis-lactone ring system isolated from the roots of
E. kansuensis ( Yan et al., 2019 )
.\ Euphordraculoates A ( 452 ) and B ( 453 ), featuring tigliane diterpenoids with two novel carbon skeletons, were characterized as natural product from
E. dracunculoides
and semisynthetic product, respectively (
). Heliosterpenoids A and B ( 454–455 ), two unprecedented jatrophane-derived diterpenoid esters with a novel 5/6/4/6-fused tetracyclic ring skeleton, were isolated from the whole plant of
E. helioscopia ( Mai et al., 2017 )
.

Due to the diversity of diterpenoid skeletons, diterpenoids have become a hot spot in the field of natural product chemistry. The diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
plants were found to have multiple hydroxyl groups, which may be the basis for diterpenoids to easily produce new compounds and new skeletons. These hydroxyl groups are easily linked with different groups and become new compounds. It is very important that these hydroxyl groups may undergo elimination reactions to form double bonds, and the double bonds undergo other reactions to change the framework of the diterpenoids.

sec.title:
4. Distribution of
Euphorbia
diterpenoids
sec.p:
A total of 455 previously undescribed diterpenoids have been isolated from the 53 spices of
Euphorbia
genus during 2013–2019 (Table 4). Most of these were isolated from
E. peplus , E. milii , E. micratina , E. dracunculoides , E. sogdiana , E. glomeralans , E. antiquorum , E. hylonoma , E.

esula, E. royleana , E. neriifolia , E. ebracteolata , E. helioscopia , E. pekinensis , E. lathyris , E. pseudocactus , E. sanctae-catharina and E. fischeriana
. Many
Euphorbia
diterpenoids with novel skeletons have been isolated from
Euphorbia
genus these years, which were isolated from the plants that haven’ t been investigated before, such as
E. rapulum , E. pilosa , E. piscatoria , E. strachey , E. lumulata , E. jolkinii , E. antiquorum , E. hylonoma , E. alatavica , E. gaditana , E. erythradenia , E. squamosa , E. glomeralans , E. dulcis , E. taurinensis , E. nicaeensis , E. exigua , E. osyridea , E. connata , E. soongarica , E. sikkimensis , E. dracunculoides , E. microsciadia , E. clementei , E. pseudocactus , E. sanctae-catharina
and
E. milii
.

sec.title: 5. Biological activity
sec.p:
Most of the diterpenoids isolated from
Euphorbia
genus in 2013–2019 show significant biological activity, including anticancer, K
+
channel inhibition, inhibitory effects on α- glucosidase, antifeedant, antivirus, antimicrobial effect, vasoactive effect, anti-inflammation, immunomodulation, antimalarial, neuroprotection, inhibition of osteoclast formation, and MDR (multiple drug resistance) reversal.

sec.title: 5.1. Anticancer activity
sec.p:
Among the 455
Euphorbia
diterpenoids, most were tested for their anticancer activity. Compounds with different skeleton types ( ent -abietane, ingenane, ingol, lathyrane, tigliane, rosane, cembrane, jatrophane, myrsinol, atisane, isopimarane) were proven to have moderate or strong antiproliferative effects on different human cancer cell lines (HL-60, SMMC-7721, MDA-MB-231, A549, HEP3B, SW-480, MCF-7, U937, HepG2, HeLa, P388, 786-O, etc .).

According to the cytotoxic activity of all diterpenoids in recent years, most ingenane-type diterpenoids have good inhibitory effects on cancer cell. The IC 50 value is basically within 20 μM the inhibitory activity on the A549 cell line is very obvious, and its IC 50 value even reaches 3 μM. For abietane-type diterpenoids isolated in recent years, the hydroxyl group at C-3 has a great influence on increasing their anticancer activity. For atisane-type diterpenoids, the anticancer activity of type A diterpenoids is better than that of type B diterpenoids, and the orientation of the hydroxyl group at C-3 also shows some influence on their anticancer activity ( β -hydroxyl is better than α -hydroxyl). Similarly, rosane diterpenoids also have good anticancer activity, and their IC 50 value is less than 20 μM.

sec.title: 5.2. Antivirus activity
sec.p: Many types of diterpenoids, especially those from the ingenane, abietane, atisane, and rosane classes, as well as a number with novel skeletal structures, have been tested for their antiviral activity [HIV (human immunodeficiencyvirus), RSV (rous sarcoma virus), HRV3 (human rotavirus), EBV (Epstein-Barr virus)].

Regarding antiviral activity, abietane diterpenes with five-membered lactone rings have better antiviral activity. It is worth noting that ingenane-type diterpenoids with long fatty acid chain substitutions at C-20 show better antiviral activity.

sec.title: 5.3. Anti-inflammatory activity
sec.p: Many types of diterpenoids, such as kaurane, lathyrane, ingenane, abietane, jatrophane, rosane, pepluane, and paraliane show anti-inflammatory activity.
Most of the lower diterpenoids have good anti-inflammatory activities, and the abietane-type diterpenoids in the higher diterpenoids also show prominent anti-inflammatory activities.

sec.title: 5.4. Antibacterial activity
sec.p: Among the diterpenoids from 2013 to 2019, rosane, cyclomyrsinol and myrsinol-type diterpenoids showed antibacterial activity.

sec.title: 5.5. MDR-reversing activity
sec.p: Among the 455 diterpenoids, many showed MDR-reversing activity, such as jatrophane, segetane, and some diterpenoids with unprecedented skeleton. And most diterpenoids with MDR-reversing activity belong to jatrophane-type diterpenoids.
According to the structures of these compounds, almost all the compounds with better MDR reversing activity are lower diterpenoids, and they all possess an OBz group at C-3.

sec.title: 5.6. Other activities
sec.p:
Some of these diterpenoids have been tested for their antifeedant activity. A jatrophane-type ( 209 ) and a lathyrane-type diterpenoid ( 330 ) showed significant antifeedant activity against the plant-feeding insect
Helicoverpa armigera
, with EC 50 values ranging from 2.05 to 4.34 μg/cm 2 (
). An ingenane-type diterpenoid ( 175 ) exhibited moderate antifeedant activity against
Spodoptera exigua
, with EC 50 values of 17.88 and 17.71 μg/cm 2 , respectively (
).

Four jatrophane-type (
248 – 249
, 256 , 278 ) (
, 2018) and two diterpenoids with an novel skeleton (
440 – 441
) (
) showed the notable inhibitory effect on Kir3.4/3.1, Kv 1.3, Kv 11.1 channels, demonstrating these compounds might be used for the development of new therapeutic agents against atrial fibrillation.

Three jatrophane-type diterpenoids ( 212 , 218 , 222 ) showed neuroprotective activities against serum deprivation-induced PC12 cell damage (
).

A highly modified rosane diterpenoid ( 444 ) exhibited inhibition of receptor activation of nuclear factor kappa B ligand (RANKL)-induced osteoclast formation (IC 50 = 12.6 μM) (
).

Although these activities have rarely been studied in recent years, this does not mean that they have no research value. There are too few active compounds for these diseases, therefore we can obtain some inspiration from these active compounds. They make a great contribution to naturally occurring medicines.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p:
In the past seven years, more than 400 diterpenoids with cembrane, casbane, ent -labdane, gaditanone, ingenane, ingol, jatrophane, jatropholane, lathyrane, cyclomyrsinol, myrsinol, premyrsinol, paraliane, pepluane, rhamnofolane, dolabrane, presegetane, segetane, tiliane, abietane, atisane, kaurane, isopimarene, rosane, cyclojatrophane, expoxyjatropholane and diterpenoids with novel skeletons have been isolated from different
Euphorbia species.
Compared to prior research, there were more previously undescribed diterpenoids isolated from the
Euphorbia
genus, and more than two kinds of higher diterpenoids could always be found in the same plant. Surprisingly, 105 previously undescribed jatrophane-type diterpenoids were isolated from this genus, which is the major type of diterpenoid present.

There are abundant diterpenoids in the genus
Euphorbia
, and most
Euphorbia
diterpenoids show significant or moderate biological activity, which opens up new opportunities for the development of clinical drugs. Among these isolated diterpenoids, jatrophane-type diterpenoids showed many kinds of activity, including anticancer, K
+
channel inhibitory, antifeedant, anti-inflammatory, antimalarial, neuroprotective and MDR-reversing effects.

However, most studies have been conducted using in vitro assays. Even if some compounds showed strong in vitro activity, no further studies have been conducted, and few studies have focused on specific molecular targets or pathways. Therefore, in-depth investigation of these diterpenoids’ molecular targets and mechanisms is necessary for their further modification based on target protein structures.
